title: 114_hr5922
content: The Act is titled the "Saving Federal Dollars Through Better Use of Government Purchase and Travel Cards Act of 2016". It defines terms like "improper payment" and "questionable transaction", and introduces the concept of "strategic sourcing". The Act also focuses on expanding the use of data analytics. The Act mandates the development of a strategy to expand data analytics in managing government purchase and travel card programs. This includes identifying questionable transactions, recovering improper payments, streamlining administrative processes, and developing metrics for purchase and travel card usage. The development of a plan to create a library of analytics tools and data sources for Federal agencies, including inspectors general, to assist in identifying potential emphasis areas for purchase and travel card management and oversight activities. SEC. 4. GUIDANCE ON IMPROVING INFORMATION SHARING TO CURB IMPROPER PAYMENTS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with relevant agencies, will issue guidance to improve information sharing among government agencies to identify high-risk activities, review reports on questionable transactions, and facilitate the sharing of information. The Director will issue guidance to improve information sharing among government agencies regarding high-risk activities, questionable transactions, and fraud schemes, including sharing with the General Services Administration Office of Charge Card Management and Federal agency officials. Other requirements may be included as determined appropriate for this Act. SEC. 5. INTERAGENCY CHARGE CARD DATA MANAGEMENT GROUP. Establishment of a purchase and travel charge card data management group by the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to develop best practices related to charge card-issuing banks, review of agency transaction data, and other payment opportunities. The group will meet regularly for three years and include relevant agencies. The management group, established by the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will meet regularly for three years. It will include agencies described in the Government Charge Card Abuse Prevention Act of 2012 and others identified by the Administrator and Director. SEC. 6. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The General Services Administration must submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the Act, including metrics for reducing improper payments and improving card-based payment utilization. Federal agencies must also report on their implementation activities, and the Office of Management and Budget will submit a consolidated report to Congress. The Administrator of General Services will submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment, identifying additional savings opportunities for government agencies under the Federal charge card programs. This report may be combined with other reports required by the Act.
